title: European stocks trade lower in first opportunity to react to start of Trump impeachment process
text:
Stocks in Europe traded lower on Wednesday amid the political cloud surrounding President Trump ahead of key trade talks between the U.S. and China.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced an impeachment inquiry after European markets had closed. “The political turmoil around Donald Trump’s official impeachment inquiry, combined to rising fears of a no agreement with China in October trade talks turned the risk sentiment off across the global markets,” said Ipek Ozkardeskaya, senior market analyst at London Capital Group.

One piece of good news on the trade front, however, came as China said it was preparing to buy more U.S. pork.

The Stoxx Europe 600 SXXP, -1.08% slumped 1.15% to 385.37 as banks including BNP Paribas BNP, -1.29% and Credit Suisse CSGN, -2.95% declined.

The German DAX DAX, -1.01% skidded 1.01% to 12182.45, the French CAC 40 PX1, -1.30% tumbled 1.34% to 5552.85 and the U.K. FTSE 100 UKX, -0.47% declined 0.84% to 7229.94.

Of stocks in the spotlight, Electricite de France shares EDF, -6.03% slumped 6% as the company said the completion cost for its Hinkley C project has climbed to between £21.5 billion and £22.5 billion, an increase of £1.9 billion to £2.9 billion.

U.K. grocery chain J Sainsbury SBRY, +2.35% rose 1.2% as the company reported improving sales momentum as same-store sales excluding fuel slipped 0.2% in the second quarter. At its capital markets day, it said it can structurally reduce costs by around £500 million over five years. It said full-year underlying pretax profit will be in line with expectations.

Halma HLMA, -3.45% shares fell 3.5% as the U.K.-listed smoke detector maker reported performance in line with the board’s expectations and said its M&A teams “continue to be active.”
description: Stocks in Europe traded lower on Wednesday amid the political cloud surrounding President Trump ahead of key trade talks between the U.S. and China.
